Закрыв глаза, вы начинаете успокаиваться, когда земля укачивает вас в своих объятиях.	With your eyes closed, you begin to calm as the earth cradles you in its arms.
The melody of the waterfall lulls you deeper inside.	The melody of the waterfall lulls you deeper inside.	Мелодия водопада убаюкивает вас глубже внутри.	The melody of the waterfall lulls you deeper inside.
Bring your attention to your feet and toes.	Bring your attention to your feet and toes.	Перенесите внимание на ступни и пальцы ног.	Bring your attention to your feet and toes.
Notice how they feel: acknowledge any parts in your feet and toes.	Notice how they feel: acknowledge any parts in your feet and toes.	Обратите внимание на то, как они себя чувствуют: обратите внимание на любые части ваших ступней и пальцев ног.	Notice how they feel: acknowledge any parts in your feet and toes.
Focus on the part or parts you notice there.	Focus on the part or parts you notice there.	Сосредоточьтесь на той части или частях, которые вы там заметили.	Focus on the part or parts you notice there.
As you focus, what more do you notice?	As you focus, what more do you notice?	Когда вы сосредотачиваетесь, что еще вы замечаете?	As you focus, what more do you notice?
Move your attention to your legs. Notice how they feel.	Move your attention to your legs. Notice how they feel.	Переместите внимание на ноги. Обратите внимание на то, что они чувствуют.	Move your attention to your legs. Notice how they feel.
Bring your attention to any parts that use your legs; for now, just allow them to be there while you focus on them.	Bring your attention to any parts that use your legs; for now, just allow them to be there while you focus on them.	Обратите внимание на все части тела, которые задействуют ваши ноги; а пока просто позвольте им быть рядом, пока вы сосредотачиваетесь на них.	Bring your attention to any parts that use your legs; for now, just allow them to be there while you focus on them.
How do you feel toward the parts you notice in your legs?	How do you feel toward the parts you notice in your legs?	Что вы чувствуете по отношению к тем частям, которые замечаете на своих ногах?	How do you feel toward the parts you notice in your legs?
Move your awareness to your thighs, what do you notice here? Which parts live in your thighs?	Move your awareness to your thighs, what do you notice here? Which parts live in your thighs?	Переместите свое внимание на бедра. Что вы здесь заметили? Какие части живут в ваших бедрах?	Move your awareness to your thighs, what do you notice here? Which parts live in your thighs?
Now move to your sit bone. Breathe into this area of your body and see what you notice. Be with whatever you find there.	Now move to your sit bone. Breathe into this area of your body and see what you notice. Be with whatever you find there.	Теперь перейдите к седалищной кости. Дышите в эту область вашего тела и посмотрите, что вы заметите. Будьте со всем, что вы там найдете.	Now move to your sit bone. Breathe into this area of your body and see what you notice. Be with whatever you find there.
Bring your attention to your hips. Notice and allow whatever is present.	Bring your attention to your hips. Notice and allow whatever is present.	Перенесите внимание на бедра. Замечайте и позволяйте всему, что присутствует.	Bring your attention to your hips. Notice and allow whatever is present.
As you pay more attention to your hips, what do you experience?	As you pay more attention to your hips, what do you experience?	Что вы испытываете, уделяя больше внимания бедрам?	As you pay more attention to your hips, what do you experience?
Move your awareness around to your stomach or abdomen area. Notice if there are any sensations here, not to change them, just to bring awareness.	Move your awareness around to your stomach or abdomen area. Notice if there are any sensations here, not to change them, just to bring awareness.	Переместите свое внимание на живот или область живота. Обратите внимание, есть ли здесь какие-либо ощущения, но не для того, чтобы их изменить, а просто для того, чтобы внести осознанность.	Move your awareness around to your stomach or abdomen area. Notice if there are any sensations here, not to change them, just to bring awareness.
How do you feel toward what you’re experiencing in your stomach?	How do you feel toward what you’re experiencing in your stomach?	Как вы относитесь к тому, что испытываете в желудке?	How do you feel toward what you’re experiencing in your stomach?
Take your attention around to your back. Take your time moving up and down your back noticing any sensations, tightness, or tension.	Take your attention around to your back. Take your time moving up and down your back noticing any sensations, tightness, or tension.	Переведите свое внимание на спину. Не торопитесь, двигаясь вверх и вниз по спине, замечая любые ощущения, стеснение или напряжение.	Take your attention around to your back. Take your time moving up and down your back noticing any sensations, tightness, or tension.
Travel from your back up to your shoulders. What do you notice here? Are your shoulders up near your ears? Are they relaxed and loose? Whatever you notice is okay.	Travel from your back up to your shoulders. What do you notice here? Are your shoulders up near your ears? Are they relaxed and loose? Whatever you notice is okay.	Двигайтесь от спины до плеч. Что вы здесь заметили? Ваши плечи приподняты возле ушей? Они расслаблены и свободны? Все, что вы замечаете, это нормально.	Travel from your back up to your shoulders. What do you notice here? Are your shoulders up near your ears? Are they relaxed and loose? Whatever you notice is okay.
Move your awareness to your heart. Feel your heartbeat. Is your heart space open, closed, tight, warm, or expansive? Notice and allow what’s happening.	Move your awareness to your heart. Feel your heartbeat. Is your heart space open, closed, tight, warm, or expansive? Notice and allow what’s happening.	Переместите свое осознание в свое сердце. Почувствуйте свое сердцебиение. Пространство вашего сердца открытое, закрытое, тесное, теплое или обширное? Замечайте и позволяйте происходящему.	Move your awareness to your heart. Feel your heartbeat. Is your heart space open, closed, tight, warm, or expansive? Notice and allow what’s happening.
Pull your awareness down your arms and into your hands. Notice whatever is present. How do parts use your arms or hands?	Pull your awareness down your arms and into your hands. Notice whatever is present. How do parts use your arms or hands?	Потяните свое осознание вниз по рукам и в ладони. Обратите внимание на все, что присутствует. Как части используют ваши руки или кисти?	Pull your awareness down your arms and into your hands. Notice whatever is present. How do parts use your arms or hands?
Focus on those parts and see what else you notice.	Focus on those parts and see what else you notice.	Сосредоточьтесь на этих частях и посмотрите, что еще вы заметите.	Focus on those parts and see what else you notice.
Move your attention to your throat. Notice the air as it passes through your throat. Are there parts that use your throat? Focus on those parts. Be with what you find here.	Move your attention to your throat. Notice the air as it passes through your throat. Are there parts that use your throat? Focus on those parts. Be with what you find here.	Переместите внимание на горло. Обратите внимание на воздух, проходящий через горло. Есть ли части, которые используют ваше горло? Сосредоточьтесь на этих частях. Будьте с тем, что вы найдете здесь.	Move your attention to your throat. Notice the air as it passes through your throat. Are there parts that use your throat? Focus on those parts. Be with what you find here.
Pull your awareness up to your face and jaw. Can you feel your expression? Is your jaw tight or relaxed? Just notice.	Pull your awareness up to your face and jaw. Can you feel your expression? Is your jaw tight or relaxed? Just notice.	Поднимите свое внимание к лицу и челюсти. Чувствуете ли вы выражение своего лица? Ваша челюсть напряжена или расслаблена? Просто обратите внимание.	Pull your awareness up to your face and jaw. Can you feel your expression? Is your jaw tight or relaxed? Just notice.
Now to your eyes, ears, and forehead. Simply be with whatever is present. Notice the parts that show up in your eyes, ears, and forehead. How do you feel toward these parts?	Now to your eyes, ears, and forehead. Simply be with whatever is present. Notice the parts that show up in your eyes, ears, and forehead. How do you feel toward these parts?	Теперь о ваших глазах, ушах и лбу. Просто будьте с тем, что присутствует. Обратите внимание на части, которые появляются в ваших глазах, ушах и лбу. Как вы относитесь к этим местам?	Now to your eyes, ears, and forehead. Simply be with whatever is present. Notice the parts that show up in your eyes, ears, and forehead. How do you feel toward these parts?
Bring your attention to the top of your head. What do you sense here? As you focus on the top of your head, what more do you notice? Breathe into the top of your head.	Bring your attention to the top of your head. What do you sense here? As you focus on the top of your head, what more do you notice? Breathe into the top of your head.	Перенесите свое внимание на макушку головы. Что вы здесь чувствуете? Когда вы фокусируетесь на макушке головы, что еще вы замечаете? Дышите в макушку головы.	Bring your attention to the top of your head. What do you sense here? As you focus on the top of your head, what more do you notice? Breathe into the top of your head.
Breathe into your whole body, noticing your entire body breathing. Every single part you noticed is breathing.	Breathe into your whole body, noticing your entire body breathing. Every single part you noticed is breathing.	Дышите всем телом, замечая, как дышит все тело. Каждая часть, которую вы заметили, является дыханием.	Breathe into your whole body, noticing your entire body breathing. Every single part you noticed is breathing.
Bring awareness to how your body feels. From the top of your head back down to your toes, scan each part and notice how your body feels.	Bring awareness to how your body feels. From the top of your head back down to your toes, scan each part and notice how your body feels.	Осознайте, что чувствует ваше тело. От макушки головы до пальцев ног сканируйте каждую часть и обратите внимание на ощущения вашего тела.	Bring awareness to how your body feels. From the top of your head back down to your toes, scan each part and notice how your body feels.
If there are parts you need to return to, set an intention with them to do so.	If there are parts you need to return to, set an intention with them to do so.	Если есть части, к которым вам нужно вернуться, поставьте перед ними намерение сделать это.	If there are parts you need to return to, set an intention with them to do so.
Express gratitude for what your parts shared.	Express gratitude for what your parts shared.	Выразите благодарность за то, чем поделились ваши части.	Express gratitude for what your parts shared.
Bring your awareness to your breath and breathe as you re-enter this moment and space.	Bring your awareness to your breath and breathe as you re-enter this moment and space.	Направьте свое осознание на свое дыхание и дышите, возвращаясь в этот момент и пространство.	Bring your awareness to your breath and breathe as you re-enter this moment and space.
When it feels right, you can slowly open your eyes.	When it feels right, you can slowly open your eyes.	Когда вы почувствуете, что это правильно, вы можете медленно открыть глаза.	When it feels right, you can slowly open your eyes.
Exercise 1: Journal Capture	Exercise 1: Journal Capture	Упражнение 1. Ведение журнала	Exercise 1: Journal Capture
Journal what you would like to capture from this meditation, like a revelation, reflection, or anything significant you want to remember from this experience.	Journal what you would like to capture from this meditation, like a revelation, reflection, or anything significant you want to remember from this experience.	Запишите то, что вы хотели бы уловить в результате этой медитации, например, откровение, размышление или что-то важное, что вы хотите запомнить из этого опыта.	Journal what you would like to capture from this meditation, like a revelation, reflection, or anything significant you want to remember from this experience.
Exercise 2: Waterfall Journal Questions	Exercise 2: Waterfall Journal Questions	Упражнение 2: Вопросы для журнала «Водопад»	Exercise 2: Waterfall Journal Questions
After you’ve done the Waterfall meditation and written your quick Journal Capture, take some time to explore more deeply by responding to the following journal prompts.	After you’ve done the Waterfall meditation and written your quick Journal Capture, take some time to explore more deeply by responding to the following journal prompts.	После того как вы выполнили медитацию «Водопад» и написали краткий дневник, потратьте некоторое время на более глубокое изучение, ответив на следующие подсказки журнала.	After you’ve done the Waterfall meditation and written your quick Journal Capture, take some time to explore more deeply by responding to the following journal prompts.
What did you learn about your parts and how they express in your body?	What did you learn about your parts and how they express in your body?	Что вы узнали о своих частях и о том, как они выражаются в вашем теле?	What did you learn about your parts and how they express in your body?
How did your body feel at the end of this meditation?	How did your body feel at the end of this meditation?	Что чувствовало ваше тело в конце медитации?	How did your body feel at the end of this meditation?
What parts were most noticeable, and where were they located in your body?	What parts were most noticeable, and where were they located in your body?	Какие части вашего тела были наиболее заметными и где они располагались?	What parts were most noticeable, and where were they located in your body?
How might knowing how your parts use your body benefit you?	How might knowing how your parts use your body benefit you?	Какую пользу вам может принести знание того, как ваши части тела используют ваше тело?	How might knowing how your parts use your body benefit you?
Did you experience any familiar sensations in your body? If so, explain.	Did you experience any familiar sensations in your body? If so, explain.	Испытывали ли вы какие-либо знакомые ощущения в теле? Если да, объясните.	Did you experience any familiar sensations in your body? If so, explain.
Did you have any new or unfamiliar sensations in your body? If so, explain.	Did you have any new or unfamiliar sensations in your body? If so, explain.	Появились ли у вас какие-то новые или незнакомые ощущения в теле? Если да, объясните.	Did you have any new or unfamiliar sensations in your body? If so, explain.
Which parts did you commit to return to?	Which parts did you commit to return to?	В какие части вы обязались вернуться?	Which parts did you commit to return to?
Exercise 3: Naming the Sensations	Exercise 3: Naming the Sensations	Упражнение 3: Назовите ощущения	Exercise 3: Naming the Sensations
Using the table below as a guide, choose the words that describe the bodily sensations you experienced during the meditation. Write them in your journal.	Using the table below as a guide, choose the words that describe the bodily sensations you experienced during the meditation. Write them in your journal.	Используя приведенную ниже таблицу в качестве руководства, выберите слова, которые описывают телесные ощущения, которые вы испытали во время медитации. Запишите их в свой дневник. Exercise 4: Where Parts Live in Your Body	Exercise 4: Where Parts Live in Your Body	Упражнение 4. Где в вашем теле живут части	Exercise 4: Where Parts Live in Your Body
In your journal, sketch a rough outline of your body, then indicate the place of your most dominant parts. Draw a line from that area of the body, and write a word or two to describe the sensations experienced in that area. Draw a line from that area of the body, and write a word or two to describe the sensations experienced in that area. In your journal, sketch a rough outline of your body, then indicate the place of your most dominant parts. Draw a line from that area of the body, and write a word or two to describe the sensations experienced in that area.
CHAPTER 9	CHAPTER 9	ГЛАВА 9	CHAPTER 9
The Weary One	The Weary One	Усталый	The Weary One
Helping Exhausted Parts	Helping Exhausted Parts	Помощь изношенным частям	Helping Exhausted Parts
When I was traveling with my husband in Mexico a few years ago, I became acutely aware of a part that got frustrated, agitated, irritable, and even angry when life didn’t go as planned. The first situation occurred on the ferry to Isla Holbox. I selected seats for us, but he beckoned me to seats further to the front and I moved to his preferred seats. The ferry continued to fill up, with few seats left by the time I put my bags away and settled in next to him. My seat was reclined. I tried to bring the seat back up, and it wouldn’t budge. It was broken. My husband reached across me to help. The seat didn’t move. I was sitting at an uncomfortable angle, and instantly I felt heat rising in my torso and face. I heard a voice say, “If we had stayed in the seats I chose, I wouldn’t be stuck in this broken seat.” I looked around the ferry for alternative seats; none were available. I started cussing under my breath and blaming my husband for my discomfort. I said to him in an accusatory tone, “We should have stayed in the other seats.” My perceptual field narrowed, and all I could see was him sitting comfortably and me uncomfortable. My body was tense and rigid. My mouth was tight with clenched teeth, my breathing was shallow, and my internal temperature rose. I was hot both physically and emotionally. I was twisting and turning, trying to find a satisfactory way to endure the 30-minute ride. My husband offered me his seat, and my part, in its highly irritable and angry state, growled, “No, I want this seat to work.”	When I was traveling with my husband in Mexico a few years ago, I became acutely aware of a part that got frustrated, agitated, irritable, and even angry when life didn’t go as planned. The first situation occurred on the ferry to Isla Holbox. I selected seats for us, but he beckoned me to seats further to the front and I moved to his preferred seats. The ferry continued to fill up, with few seats left by the time I put my bags away and settled in next to him. My seat was reclined. I tried to bring the seat back up, and it wouldn’t budge. It was broken. My husband reached across me to help. The seat didn’t move. I was sitting at an uncomfortable angle, and instantly I felt heat rising in my torso and face. I heard a voice say, “If we had stayed in the seats I chose, I wouldn’t be stuck in this broken seat.” I looked around the ferry for alternative seats; none were available. I started cussing under my breath and blaming my husband for my discomfort. I said to him in an accusatory tone, “We should have stayed in the other seats.” My perceptual field narrowed, and all I could see was him sitting comfortably and me uncomfortable. My body was tense and rigid. My mouth was tight with clenched teeth, my breathing was shallow, and my internal temperature rose. I was hot both physically and emotionally. I was twisting and turning, trying to find a satisfactory way to endure the 30-minute ride. My husband offered me his seat, and my part, in its highly irritable and angry state, growled, “No, I want this seat to work.”	Когда несколько лет назад я путешествовала с мужем по Мексике, я остро осознала часть, которая расстраивалась, волновалась, раздражалась и даже злилась, когда жизнь шла не так, как планировалось. Первая ситуация произошла на пароме до острова Холбокс. Я выбрал для нас места, но он подозвал меня на места дальше вперед, и я пересел на его любимые места. Паром продолжал заполняться, и к тому времени, когда я убрала сумки и устроилась рядом с ним, осталось мало мест. Мое сиденье было откинуто. Я попытался поднять сиденье, но оно не сдвинулось с места. Он был сломан. Мой муж потянулся ко мне, чтобы помочь. Сиденье не двигалось. Я сидел под неудобным углом и сразу почувствовал жар, поднимающийся по моему туловищу и лицу. Я услышал голос, говорящий: «Если бы мы остались на тех местах, которые я выбрал, я бы не застрял на этом сломанном сиденье». Я осмотрел паром в поисках альтернативных мест; ни один не был доступен. Я начала ругаться себе под нос и обвинять мужа в своем дискомфорте. Я сказал ему обвинительным тоном: «Надо было остаться на других местах». Поле моего восприятия сузилось, и все, что я мог видеть, это то, что он сидел удобно, а я чувствовал себя некомфортно. Мое тело было напряженным и жестким. Рот у меня был сжат, зубы сжаты, дыхание поверхностное, внутренняя температура повысилась. Мне было жарко и физически, и эмоционально. Я извивался и вертелся, пытаясь найти удовлетворительный способ выдержать 30-минутную поездку. Муж предложил мне свое место, а моя часть в крайне раздраженном и злом состоянии прорычала: «Нет, я хочу, чтобы это сиденье работало».	When I was traveling with my husband in Mexico a few years ago, I became acutely aware of a part that got frustrated, agitated, irritable, and even angry when life didn’t go as planned. The first situation occurred on the ferry to Isla Holbox. I selected seats for us, but he beckoned me to seats further to the front and I moved to his preferred seats. The ferry continued to fill up, with few seats left by the time I put my bags away and settled in next to him. My seat was reclined. I tried to bring the seat back up, and it wouldn’t budge. It was broken. My husband reached across me to help. The seat didn’t move. I was sitting at an uncomfortable angle, and instantly I felt heat rising in my torso and face. I heard a voice say, “If we had stayed in the seats I chose, I wouldn’t be stuck in this broken seat.” I looked around the ferry for alternative seats; none were available. I started cussing under my breath and blaming my husband for my discomfort. I said to him in an accusatory tone, “We should have stayed in the other seats.” My perceptual field narrowed, and all I could see was him sitting comfortably and me uncomfortable. My body was tense and rigid. My mouth was tight with clenched teeth, my breathing was shallow, and my internal temperature rose. I was hot both physically and emotionally. I was twisting and turning, trying to find a satisfactory way to endure the 30-minute ride. My husband offered me his seat, and my part, in its highly irritable and angry state, growled, “No, I want this seat to work.”
In the depth of this experience, life outside of me seems not to exist. I am only faintly aware of what is going on around me. However, when a solution is offered, my part needs time to take it in. Slowly, it allows the alternative to creep into its awareness, then gradually becomes aware of life outside of itself.	In the depth of this experience, life outside of me seems not to exist. I am only faintly aware of what is going on around me. However, when a solution is offered, my part needs time to take it in. Slowly, it allows the alternative to creep into its awareness, then gradually becomes aware of life outside of itself.	В глубине этого опыта кажется, что жизнь вне меня не существует. Я лишь смутно осознаю, что происходит вокруг меня. Однако, когда решение предлагается, моей части нужно время, чтобы принять его. Постепенно она позволяет альтернативе проникнуть в ее сознание, а затем постепенно начинает осознавать жизнь вне себя.	In the depth of this experience, life outside of me seems not to exist. I am only faintly aware of what is going on around me. However, when a solution is offered, my part needs time to take it in. Slowly, it allows the alternative to creep into its awareness, then gradually becomes aware of life outside of itself.
After 10 minutes of what felt like misery to this part, it requested to change seats with my husband. After another few minutes, I thought, “What just happened? Why did I get so frustrated and angry about being unable to sit upright for 30 minutes? Why didn’t I just recline and enjoy the ride? Or accept my husband’s initial offer to change seats?” My behavior was baffling to me. The me that didn’t understand was another part confused by what it viewed as an overreaction to the situation.	After 10 minutes of what felt like misery to this part, it requested to change seats with my husband. After another few minutes, I thought, “What just happened? Why did I get so frustrated and angry about being unable to sit upright for 30 minutes? Why didn’t I just recline and enjoy the ride? Or accept my husband’s initial offer to change seats?” My behavior was baffling to me. The me that didn’t understand was another part confused by what it viewed as an overreaction to the situation.	После 10 минут того, что казалось страданием для этой части, она попросила меня с мужем поменяться местами. Еще через несколько минут я подумал: «Что только что произошло? Почему я так расстроился и разозлился из-за того, что не мог сидеть прямо в течение 30 минут? Почему я просто не откинулся и не наслаждался поездкой? Или принять первоначальное предложение мужа пересесть?» Мое поведение меня сбивало с толку. «Я», которое не понимало, было еще одной частью, сбитой с толку тем, что оно считало чрезмерной реакцией на ситуацию.	After 10 minutes of what felt like misery to this part, it requested to change seats with my husband. After another few minutes, I thought, “What just happened? Why did I get so frustrated and angry about being unable to sit upright for 30 minutes? Why didn’t I just recline and enjoy the ride? Or accept my husband’s initial offer to change seats?” My behavior was baffling to me. The me that didn’t understand was another part confused by what it viewed as an overreaction to the situation.
On the same trip, we planned a day of sunning and relaxing at one of our favorite beach clubs. I’d packed our beach bags with sunblock, water, my iPad for reading, a hat, sunglasses, towels—I was ready. The club prepared a delicious ceviche I was looking forward to enjoying. About an hour into our beach time, the part of me that became irritable with the unexpected showed itself again when we got caught in a rainfall that hadn’t been in the forecast. Again, I became razor focused, this time about how our day was ruined by the rain. However, this time, unlike with the broken seat, there was a degree of separation from the part, because I was aware while I was in a place of high agitation and anger, life around me continued. People played in the ocean, others sat in beach chairs drinking drinks garnished with colorful umbrellas, and children laughed and ran through the rain. Most of the people around me seemed unfazed by what my part experienced as a joy-stealing event.	On the same trip, we planned a day of sunning and relaxing at one of our favorite beach clubs. I’d packed our beach bags with sunblock, water, my iPad for reading, a hat, sunglasses, towels—I was ready. The club prepared a delicious ceviche I was looking forward to enjoying. About an hour into our beach time, the part of me that became irritable with the unexpected showed itself again when we got caught in a rainfall that hadn’t been in the forecast. Again, I became razor focused, this time about how our day was ruined by the rain. However, this time, unlike with the broken seat, there was a degree of separation from the part, because I was aware while I was in a place of high agitation and anger, life around me continued. People played in the ocean, others sat in beach chairs drinking drinks garnished with colorful umbrellas, and children laughed and ran through the rain. Most of the people around me seemed unfazed by what my part experienced as a joy-stealing event.	В той же поездке мы запланировали день, чтобы позагорать и расслабиться в одном из наших любимых пляжных клубов. Я упаковала в наши пляжные сумки солнцезащитный крем, воду, iPad для чтения, шляпу, солнцезащитные очки, полотенца — я была готова. Клуб приготовил восхитительное севиче, которое я с нетерпением ждал. Примерно через час после начала пляжного отдыха та часть меня, которая раздражалась из-за неожиданностей, снова проявила себя, когда мы попали под дождь, которого не было в прогнозе. И снова я сосредоточился, на этот раз на том, как наш день был испорчен дождем. Однако на этот раз, в отличие от сломанного сиденья, произошла определенная степень отделения от части, потому что я осознавал, что пока я находился в состоянии сильного волнения и гнева, жизнь вокруг меня продолжалась. Люди играли в океане, другие сидели в шезлонгах и пили напитки, украшенные разноцветными зонтиками, а дети смеялись и бегали под дождем. Большую часть людей вокруг меня, похоже, не смутило то, что моя часть восприняла как событие, похищающее радость.	On the same trip, we planned a day of sunning and relaxing at one of our favorite beach clubs. I’d packed our beach bags with sunblock, water, my iPad for reading, a hat, sunglasses, towels—I was ready. The club prepared a delicious ceviche I was looking forward to enjoying. About an hour into our beach time, the part of me that became irritable with the unexpected showed itself again when we got caught in a rainfall that hadn’t been in the forecast. Again, I became razor focused, this time about how our day was ruined by the rain. However, this time, unlike with the broken seat, there was a degree of separation from the part, because I was aware while I was in a place of high agitation and anger, life around me continued. People played in the ocean, others sat in beach chairs drinking drinks garnished with colorful umbrellas, and children laughed and ran through the rain. Most of the people around me seemed unfazed by what my part experienced as a joy-stealing event.
The agitation over the ferry seat and the rain caused me to get curious about this part of myself. I wanted to know its story. I realized it was protecting me from something, and I wanted to know the true catalyst for its disproportional reaction to the smallest of unexpected events. By befriending this part and being curious about its story, I learned that it was tired of the automatic response it could not control. It didn’t want to overreact, but agitation and anger felt like the only responses available. Although this part didn’t know what else to do, it felt terribly exhausted.	The agitation over the ferry seat and the rain caused me to get curious about this part of myself. I wanted to know its story. I realized it was protecting me from something, and I wanted to know the true catalyst for its disproportional reaction to the smallest of unexpected events. By befriending this part and being curious about its story, I learned that it was tired of the automatic response it could not control. It didn’t want to overreact, but agitation and anger felt like the only responses available. Although this part didn’t know what else to do, it felt terribly exhausted.	Волнение из-за сиденья на пароме и дождя заставили меня заинтересоваться этой частью меня самого. Я хотел узнать его историю. Я понял, что он защищает меня от чего-то, и мне хотелось узнать истинный катализатор его непропорциональной реакции на малейшие неожиданные события. Подружившись с этой частью и заинтересовавшись ее историей, я узнал, что она устала от автоматической реакции, которую не могла контролировать. Он не хотел слишком остро реагировать, но волнение и гнев казались единственными доступными ответами. Хотя эта часть не знала, что еще делать, она чувствовала себя ужасно утомленной.	The agitation over the ferry seat and the rain caused me to get curious about this part of myself. I wanted to know its story. I realized it was protecting me from something, and I wanted to know the true catalyst for its disproportional reaction to the smallest of unexpected events. By befriending this part and being curious about its story, I learned that it was tired of the automatic response it could not control. It didn’t want to overreact, but agitation and anger felt like the only responses available. Although this part didn’t know what else to do, it felt terribly exhausted.
IFS CONCEPT: HOPE MERCHANT	IFS CONCEPT: HOPE MERCHANT	КОНЦЕПЦИЯ IFS: НАДЕЖДА ТОРГОВЦА	IFS CONCEPT: HOPE MERCHANT
Parts become exhausted by the extreme roles they’ve been forced into. Protectors are highly committed to their jobs, even risking complete exhaustion in protecting the system from the intense emotions of exiles and other parts. In order to support our hard-working protectors, we want to validate their experiences, appreciate how hard they work to keep us safe, and offer opportunity to rest and possibly give up their roles. Self, as what we call the Hope Merchant in IFS, is not offering blind hope to parts. The offering is specific to what parts need to willingly relinquish their role. We can support our exhausted parts and offer them hope that things can improve.	Parts become exhausted by the extreme roles they’ve been forced into. Protectors are highly committed to their jobs, even risking complete exhaustion in protecting the system from the intense emotions of exiles and other parts. In order to support our hard-working protectors, we want to validate their experiences, appreciate how hard they work to keep us safe, and offer opportunity to rest and possibly give up their roles. Self, as what we call the Hope Merchant in IFS, is not offering blind hope to parts. The offering is specific to what parts need to willingly relinquish their role. We can support our exhausted parts and offer them hope that things can improve.	Части утомляются экстремальными ролями, которые им навязали. Защитники очень преданы своей работе, даже рискуя полностью истощиться, защищая систему от сильных эмоций изгнанников и других частей. Чтобы поддержать наших трудолюбивых защитников, мы хотим подтвердить их опыт, оценить, как усердно они работают, чтобы обеспечить нашу безопасность, и предложить возможность отдохнуть и, возможно, отказаться от своих ролей. «Я», как то, что мы называем «Торговец надеждой» в IFS, не предлагает слепую надежду частям. Предложение специально предназначено для тех частей, которые должны добровольно отказаться от своей роли. Мы можем поддержать наши измученные части и дать им надежду на улучшение ситуации.	Parts become exhausted by the extreme roles they’ve been forced into. Protectors are highly committed to their jobs, even risking complete exhaustion in protecting the system from the intense emotions of exiles and other parts. In order to support our hard-working protectors, we want to validate their experiences, appreciate how hard they work to keep us safe, and offer opportunity to rest and possibly give up their roles. Self, as what we call the Hope Merchant in IFS, is not offering blind hope to parts. The offering is specific to what parts need to willingly relinquish their role. We can support our exhausted parts and offer them hope that things can improve.
In Chapter 2, we met two types of protectors: proactive protectors (managers) that carry the burden of responsibility and protect through control, and reactive protectors (firefighters) that have the burden of impulsivity and protect by releasing emotional pressure. Both proactive and reactive parts do what they do, believe what they believe, and employ the strategies they do because they don’t know any other way. They hold that what they are doing really does keep us safe. Our parts are stuck in a rut of keeping us busy and controlled so we don’t experience emotional pain and emptiness, or swiftly taking us out of the pain when it emerges. But protectors aren’t good at their jobs. We still endure situations and people in life that activate those unhealed places within. Then why do they do it? Why do they rely on the same tactics over and over?	In Chapter 2, we met two types of protectors: proactive protectors (managers) that carry the burden of responsibility and protect through control, and reactive protectors (firefighters) that have the burden of impulsivity and protect by releasing emotional pressure. Both proactive and reactive parts do what they do, believe what they believe, and employ the strategies they do because they don’t know any other way. They hold that what they are doing really does keep us safe. Our parts are stuck in a rut of keeping us busy and controlled so we don’t experience emotional pain and emptiness, or swiftly taking us out of the pain when it emerges. But protectors aren’t good at their jobs. We still endure situations and people in life that activate those unhealed places within. Then why do they do it? Why do they rely on the same tactics over and over?	В главе 2 мы познакомились с двумя типами защитников: проактивными защитниками (менеджерами), которые несут бремя ответственности и защищают посредством контроля, и реактивными защитниками (пожарными), которые несут бремя импульсивности и защищают, снимая эмоциональное давление. И проактивная, и реактивная части делают то, что делают, верят в то, во что верят, и применяют стратегии, которые используют, потому что не знают другого пути. Они считают, что то, что они делают, действительно обеспечивает нашу безопасность. Наши части застряли в рутине, заставляя нас быть занятыми и контролировать себя, чтобы мы не испытывали эмоциональную боль и пустоту или быстро избавлялись от боли, когда она появляется. Но защитники не очень хороши в своей работе. Мы все еще терпим ситуации и людей в жизни, которые активизируют эти неизлечимые места внутри. Тогда почему они это делают? Почему они снова и снова полагаются на одну и ту же тактику?	In Chapter 2, we met two types of protectors: proactive protectors (managers) that carry the burden of responsibility and protect through control, and reactive protectors (firefighters) that have the burden of impulsivity and protect by releasing emotional pressure. Both proactive and reactive parts do what they do, believe what they believe, and employ the strategies they do because they don’t know any other way. They hold that what they are doing really does keep us safe. Our parts are stuck in a rut of keeping us busy and controlled so we don’t experience emotional pain and emptiness, or swiftly taking us out of the pain when it emerges. But protectors aren’t good at their jobs. We still endure situations and people in life that activate those unhealed places within. Then why do they do it? Why do they rely on the same tactics over and over?
They do so for three main reasons. First, they aren’t aware of any other choice. At some point in their past the strategies they employ made sense, offered relief, and in some ways kept us safe. However, over years and years of use, the tactics have lost whatever effectiveness and usefulness they once possessed. Second, protective parts believe something bad will happen if they stop protecting us. They are the barrier between us and hurt, pain, and even death. From their perspective, not protecting us in the manner they do is not an option. They have sworn to protect us at all costs, and they take their job very seriously. They can’t quit. If they do, they fear what will happen to the one they protect. Even when they become weary and ineffective, they won’t stop, because every time their strategies offer even a small amount of protection from pain, they are motivated to stay the course. The third and final reason our parts continue to do what doesn’t work is that they have no awareness of Self, no relationship with Self, or no trust in Self. Remember, these parts took on their job responsibilities in most cases when we were very young. They may have felt alone and had to figure things out for themselves. With this mindset, they came up with the best solution they could at the time. They did so then and continue to do so now without connection with Self. If parts knew they no longer had to carry the burden of being responsible for our safety—if they knew there’s a resource within that can help—most would gladly consider, if not readily accept, the assistance. That said, parts may have learned through their lived experience not to trust Self. Expressing qualities of Self such as confidence, courage, and/or curiosity could have resulted in belittling, humiliation, abuse, or neglect. Since Self-energy was countered with harshness, parts believe Self is unsafe and not trustworthy.	They do so for three main reasons. First, they aren’t aware of any other choice. At some point in their past the strategies they employ made sense, offered relief, and in some ways kept us safe. However, over years and years of use, the tactics have lost whatever effectiveness and usefulness they once possessed. Second, protective parts believe something bad will happen if they stop protecting us. They are the barrier between us and hurt, pain, and even death. From their perspective, not protecting us in the manner they do is not an option. They have sworn to protect us at all costs, and they take their job very seriously. They can’t quit. If they do, they fear what will happen to the one they protect. Even when they become weary and ineffective, they won’t stop, because every time their strategies offer even a small amount of protection from pain, they are motivated to stay the course. The third and final reason our parts continue to do what doesn’t work is that they have no awareness of Self, no relationship with Self, or no trust in Self. Remember, these parts took on their job responsibilities in most cases when we were very young. They may have felt alone and had to figure things out for themselves. With this mindset, they came up with the best solution they could at the time. They did so then and continue to do so now without connection with Self. If parts knew they no longer had to carry the burden of being responsible for our safety—if they knew there’s a resource within that can help—most would gladly consider, if not readily accept, the assistance. That said, parts may have learned through their lived experience not to trust Self. Expressing qualities of Self such as confidence, courage, and/or curiosity could have resulted in belittling, humiliation, abuse, or neglect. Since Self-energy was countered with harshness, parts believe Self is unsafe and not trustworthy.	Они делают это по трем основным причинам. Во-первых, они не знают другого выбора. В какой-то момент в прошлом стратегии, которые они использовали, имели смысл, приносили облегчение и в некотором смысле защищали нас. Однако с годами использования эта тактика утратила всю эффективность и полезность, которыми она когда-то обладала. Во-вторых, защитные части считают, что если они перестанут нас защищать, произойдет что-то плохое. Они — барьер между нами и болью, болью и даже смертью. С их точки зрения, не защищать нас так, как они, — это не вариант. Они поклялись защищать нас любой ценой и очень серьезно относятся к своей работе. Они не могут уйти. Если они это сделают, они боятся того, что случится с тем, кого они защищают. Даже когда они устанут и станут неэффективными, они не остановятся, потому что каждый раз, когда их стратегии предлагают хотя бы небольшую защиту от боли, у них появляется мотивация придерживаться выбранного курса. Третья и последняя причина, по которой наши части продолжают делать то, что не работает, заключается в том, что они не осознают «Я», не имеют отношений с «Я» или не доверяют «Я». Помните, эти части брали на себя свои должностные обязанности в большинстве случаев, когда мы были очень молоды. Возможно, они чувствовали себя одинокими и должны были во всем разбираться сами. С таким мышлением они нашли лучшее решение, которое могли на тот момент. Они делали это тогда и продолжают делать это сейчас, без связи с Я. Если бы части знали, что им больше не придется нести бремя ответственности за нашу безопасность, если бы они знали, что внутри есть ресурс, который может помочь, большинство из них с радостью рассмотрит, если не с готовностью примет, помощь. Тем не менее, части, возможно, на своем жизненном опыте научились не доверять Себе. Выражение таких качеств личности, как уверенность, смелость и/или любопытство, могло привести к унижению, оскорблению, оскорблению или пренебрежению. Поскольку энергии Самости было противопоставлено резкость, части считают, что Самость небезопасна и не заслуживает доверия.	They do so for three main reasons. First, they aren’t aware of any other choice. At some point in their past the strategies they employ made sense, offered relief, and in some ways kept us safe. However, over years and years of use, the tactics have lost whatever effectiveness and usefulness they once possessed. Second, protective parts believe something bad will happen if they stop protecting us. They are the barrier between us and hurt, pain, and even death. From their perspective, not protecting us in the manner they do is not an option. They have sworn to protect us at all costs, and they take their job very seriously. They can’t quit. If they do, they fear what will happen to the one they protect. Even when they become weary and ineffective, they won’t stop, because every time their strategies offer even a small amount of protection from pain, they are motivated to stay the course. The third and final reason our parts continue to do what doesn’t work is that they have no awareness of Self, no relationship with Self, or no trust in Self. Remember, these parts took on their job responsibilities in most cases when we were very young. They may have felt alone and had to figure things out for themselves. With this mindset, they came up with the best solution they could at the time. They did so then and continue to do so now without connection with Self. If parts knew they no longer had to carry the burden of being responsible for our safety—if they knew there’s a resource within that can help—most would gladly consider, if not readily accept, the assistance. That said, parts may have learned through their lived experience not to trust Self. Expressing qualities of Self such as confidence, courage, and/or curiosity could have resulted in belittling, humiliation, abuse, or neglect. Since Self-energy was countered with harshness, parts believe Self is unsafe and not trustworthy.
The antidote to the exhaustion parts feel is hope of improvement. Hope opens them to the possibility of another way of being. The way to offer them hope is through a series of questions, or Hope Merchant steps, which I’ll share here as outlined by IFS senior lead trainer Pamela Krause.1	The antidote to the exhaustion parts feel is hope of improvement. Hope opens them to the possibility of another way of being. The way to offer them hope is through a series of questions, or Hope Merchant steps, which I’ll share here as outlined by IFS senior lead trainer Pamela Krause.1	Противоядием от чувства усталости является надежда на улучшение. Надежда открывает им возможность другого образа жизни. Чтобы дать им надежду, нужно задать им ряд вопросов или шагов «Торговца надеждой», которыми я поделюсь здесь, как описано старшим ведущим тренером IFS Памелой Краузе.1	The antidote to the exhaustion parts feel is hope of improvement. Hope opens them to the possibility of another way of being. The way to offer them hope is through a series of questions, or Hope Merchant steps, which I’ll share here as outlined by IFS senior lead trainer Pamela Krause.1
The job of these tired parts is to ensure that we are never hurt the way we were when they took on their roles. To help them, we must first know what their greatest fear is, then address it. Therefore, after the part is in relationship with Self through befriending and getting to know the part’s story, we can ask the part, “What are you afraid would happen if you didn’t (fill in what the part does to protect)?” The answer points to fear of the exiled part being hurt or feeling the pain of being unlovable, worthless, or not good enough and/or overwhelming the system with its intense emotions. If the first answer given does not reflect the exile’s pain, ask the protector what it is afraid would happen if (the answer they gave) happens. For example, if the protector initially answered, “There would be no one to protect the young one.” Then ask, “What are you afraid would happen if there was no one to protect the young one?” Continue this line of questioning until you get an answer that reflects the exiled part’s pain like, “I’m afraid the young one will feel ashamed and disgusting.” Once we know the fear that motivates the protector to push through exhaustion, we offer to address it: “What if I could go to the one who feels ashamed and disgusting and heal it so you wouldn’t have to feel so exhausted? Would you be interested?”	The job of these tired parts is to ensure that we are never hurt the way we were when they took on their roles. To help them, we must first know what their greatest fear is, then address it. Therefore, after the part is in relationship with Self through befriending and getting to know the part’s story, we can ask the part, “What are you afraid would happen if you didn’t (fill in what the part does to protect)?” The answer points to fear of the exiled part being hurt or feeling the pain of being unlovable, worthless, or not good enough and/or overwhelming the system with its intense emotions. If the first answer given does not reflect the exile’s pain, ask the protector what it is afraid would happen if (the answer they gave) happens. For example, if the protector initially answered, “There would be no one to protect the young one.” Then ask, “What are you afraid would happen if there was no one to protect the young one?” Continue this line of questioning until you get an answer that reflects the exiled part’s pain like, “I’m afraid the young one will feel ashamed and disgusting.” Once we know the fear that motivates the protector to push through exhaustion, we offer to address it: “What if I could go to the one who feels ashamed and disgusting and heal it so you wouldn’t have to feel so exhausted? Would you be interested?”	Задача этих уставших частей — гарантировать, что нам никогда не будет так больно, как когда они взяли на себя свою роль. Чтобы помочь им, мы должны сначала узнать, чего они больше всего боятся, а затем заняться этим. Следовательно, после того, как часть вошла в отношения с «Я», подружившись и узнав историю части, мы можем спросить часть: «Чего вы боитесь, что произойдет, если вы этого не сделаете (впишите, что делает часть, чтобы защитить)?» Ответ указывает на страх перед тем, что изгнанная часть пострадает, или на чувство боли от того, что она непривлекательна, бесполезна или недостаточно хороша, и/или переполняет систему своими сильными эмоциями. Если первый ответ не отражает боль изгнанника, спросите защитника, чего он боится, если (ответ, который он дал), произойдет. Например, если защитник изначально ответил: «Некому будет защитить молодого». Затем спросите: «Чего вы боитесь, если бы некому было защитить детеныша?» Продолжайте эту линию вопросов, пока не получите ответ, отражающий боль изгнанной части, например: «Боюсь, молодому будет стыдно и противно». Как только мы узнаем страх, который побуждает защитника преодолевать истощение, мы предлагаем разобраться с ним: «Что, если бы я мог пойти к тому, кто чувствует стыд и отвращение, и исцелить его, чтобы вам не пришлось чувствовать себя таким изнуренным? Вам будет интересно?»	The job of these tired parts is to ensure that we are never hurt the way we were when they took on their roles. To help them, we must first know what their greatest fear is, then address it. Therefore, after the part is in relationship with Self through befriending and getting to know the part’s story, we can ask the part, “What are you afraid would happen if you didn’t (fill in what the part does to protect)?” The answer points to fear of the exiled part being hurt or feeling the pain of being unlovable, worthless, or not good enough and/or overwhelming the system with its intense emotions. If the first answer given does not reflect the exile’s pain, ask the protector what it is afraid would happen if (the answer they gave) happens. For example, if the protector initially answered, “There would be no one to protect the young one.” Then ask, “What are you afraid would happen if there was no one to protect the young one?” Continue this line of questioning until you get an answer that reflects the exiled part’s pain like, “I’m afraid the young one will feel ashamed and disgusting.” Once we know the fear that motivates the protector to push through exhaustion, we offer to address it: “What if I could go to the one who feels ashamed and disgusting and heal it so you wouldn’t have to feel so exhausted? Would you be interested?”
The most important point when asking the Hope Merchant questions is using the part’s exact words. This deepens connection and trust. The part feels heard. Since the goal is to offer hope for the part’s specific concerns, precise wording matters. Besides, if different words are used that miss the intended meaning, this may upset the part and cause it to feel misunderstood, and we may miss the opportunity to instill the hope that the part’s situation can improve.	The most important point when asking the Hope Merchant questions is using the part’s exact words. This deepens connection and trust. The part feels heard. Since the goal is to offer hope for the part’s specific concerns, precise wording matters. Besides, if different words are used that miss the intended meaning, this may upset the part and cause it to feel misunderstood, and we may miss the opportunity to instill the hope that the part’s situation can improve.	Самый важный момент при задании вопросов Торговцу Надежды — это использовать точные слова детали. Это углубляет связь и доверие. Эта часть кажется услышанной. Поскольку цель состоит в том, чтобы дать надежду на решение конкретных проблем этой части, точная формулировка имеет значение. Кроме того, если используются разные слова, которые не соответствуют предполагаемому значению, это может расстроить часть и вызвать у нее ощущение неправильного понимания, и мы можем упустить возможность вселить надежду на то, что ситуация с частью может улучшиться.	The most important point when asking the Hope Merchant questions is using the part’s exact words. This deepens connection and trust. The part feels heard. Since the goal is to offer hope for the part’s specific concerns, precise wording matters. Besides, if different words are used that miss the intended meaning, this may upset the part and cause it to feel misunderstood, and we may miss the opportunity to instill the hope that the part’s situation can improve.
Pricklee	Pricklee	Прикли	Pricklee
At the start of this chapter, I described an experience with one of my parts who becomes irritable, upset, and angry when life doesn’t go as it expected. Now I want to share with you what I learned when I got curious about why I responded as I did to the broken seat and the unanticipated rain shower. I have discovered in my personal work and my work with clients that the Self qualities of curiosity and compassion are effective ways to come into relationship with our parts. The very act of being curious allows for some separation between Self and the part. It is only with this separation that we can begin to connect with the part. If you remember my responses and actions on the ferry, I was blended with the part who was irritated; that part was in the driver’s seat. If a part is in the seat of consciousness, we cannot be with it. I often say, “I can’t be with a part when I’m being the part.” My awareness of being blended came when another part questioned why I behaved the way I did. This part had a critical tone and didn’t like the part who was irritable. The curiosity of Self came forth, and I asked the part who expressed dislike for the first part to step back and allow me to be with the part that felt irritable and angry. That part stepped back. I closed my eyes to see what I noticed inside. I felt tightness and heat in my jaw and a feeling of exasperation. The feelings were at a level that allowed separation. Self let the part know that it was curious about the part’s experiences and wanted to get to know it. Self sent the energy of curiosity to the tightness in my jaw and sat with the experience. The clenching loosened. Self thanked the part for releasing some of the tension. The feeling of exasperation decreased a bit too.	At the start of this chapter, I described an experience with one of my parts who becomes irritable, upset, and angry when life doesn’t go as it expected. Now I want to share with you what I learned when I got curious about why I responded as I did to the broken seat and the unanticipated rain shower. I have discovered in my personal work and my work with clients that the Self qualities of curiosity and compassion are effective ways to come into relationship with our parts. The very act of being curious allows for some separation between Self and the part. It is only with this separation that we can begin to connect with the part. If you remember my responses and actions on the ferry, I was blended with the part who was irritated; that part was in the driver’s seat. I often say, “I can’t be with a part when I’m being the part.” My awareness of being blended came when another part questioned why I behaved the way I did. This part had a critical tone and didn’t like the part who was irritable. The clenching loosened. Self thanked the part for releasing some of the tension. The feeling of exasperation decreased a bit too.	В начале этой главы я описал случай с одной из моих частей, которая становится раздражительной, расстроенной и злой, когда жизнь идет не так, как ожидалось. Теперь я хочу поделиться с вами тем, что я узнал, когда мне стало интересно, почему я так отреагировал на сломанное сиденье и неожиданный ливень. В своей личной работе и работе с клиентами я обнаружил, что качества Самости, такие как любопытство и сострадание, являются эффективными способами войти в отношения со своими частями. Сам акт любопытства позволяет провести некоторое разделение между «Я» и частью. Только после этого разделения мы можем начать соединяться с частью. Если вы помните мои реакции и действия на пароме, я смешался с той частью, которая была раздражена; эта часть находилась на водительском сиденье. Если часть находится в месте сознания, мы не можем быть с ней. Я часто говорю: «Я не могу быть с ролью, когда я исполняю роль». Мое осознание того, что я смешался, пришло, когда другая часть задалась вопросом, почему я веду себя таким образом. Эта часть имела критический тон и не любила раздражительную часть. Проявилось любопытство Самости, и я попросил ту часть, которая выражала неприязнь к первой части, отступить и позволить мне быть с той частью, которая чувствовала себя раздражённой и злой. Эта часть отступила. Я закрыл глаза, чтобы увидеть то, что заметил внутри. Я почувствовал напряжение и жар в челюсти и чувство раздражения. Чувства были на уровне, допускавшем разлуку. Я дал части понять, что ей интересно узнать об опыте части и что она хочет с ней познакомиться. Селф направил энергию любопытства на мои стиснутые челюсти и остался сидеть, переживая этот опыт. Сжатие ослабло. Селф поблагодарил часть за то, что она сняла часть напряжения. Чувство раздражения тоже немного уменьшилось.	At the start of this chapter, I described an experience with one of my parts who becomes irritable, upset, and angry when life doesn’t go as it expected. Now I want to share with you what I learned when I got curious about why I responded as I did to the broken seat and the unanticipated rain shower. I have discovered in my personal work and my work with clients that the Self qualities of curiosity and compassion are effective ways to come into relationship with our parts. The very act of being curious allows for some separation between Self and the part. It is only with this separation that we can begin to connect with the part. If you remember my responses and actions on the ferry, I was blended with the part who was irritated; that part was in the driver’s seat. If a part is in the seat of consciousness, we cannot be with it. I often say, “I can’t be with a part when I’m being the part.” My awareness of being blended came when another part questioned why I behaved the way I did. This part had a critical tone and didn’t like the part who was irritable. The curiosity of Self came forth, and I asked the part who expressed dislike for the first part to step back and allow me to be with the part that felt irritable and angry. That part stepped back. I closed my eyes to see what I noticed inside. I felt tightness and heat in my jaw and a feeling of exasperation. The feelings were at a level that allowed separation. Self let the part know that it was curious about the part’s experiences and wanted to get to know it. Self sent the energy of curiosity to the tightness in my jaw and sat with the experience. The clenching loosened. Self thanked the part for releasing some of the tension. The feeling of exasperation decreased a bit too.
At that point, curiosity increases. Self sends the part the energy of curiosity. Self wants to know and understand the experiences of this part and wants it to feel Self’s desire to get to know it better. Self asks, “What do you want me to know about you?” The part quickly responds, “My name is Prickly, spelled P-R-I-C-K-L-E-E, never L-Y.” The way she emphasizes never gives Self the sense that the distinction is very important. “Got it, Pricklee, L-E-E. What about life not going as you expect causes you to feel irritable?”	At that point, curiosity increases. Self sends the part the energy of curiosity. Self wants to know and understand the experiences of this part and wants it to feel Self’s desire to get to know it better. Self asks, “What do you want me to know about you?” The part quickly responds, “My name is Prickly, spelled P-R-I-C-K-L-E-E, never L-Y.” The way she emphasizes never gives Self the sense that the distinction is very important. “Got it, Pricklee, L-E-E. What about life not going as you expect causes you to feel irritable?”	В этот момент любопытство возрастает. «Я» посылает части энергию любопытства. «Я» хочет знать и понимать переживания этой части и хочет, чтобы она почувствовала желание «Я» узнать ее лучше. Селф спрашивает: «Что ты хочешь, чтобы я знал о тебе?» Часть быстро отвечает: «Меня зовут Колючий, пишется П-Р-И-К-Л-Е-Е, а не Л-Й». То, как она подчеркивает, никогда не дает Селбу ощущения, что это различие очень важно. — Понял, Прикли, Л-И-Е. А как насчет того, что жизнь идет не так, как вы ожидаете, и это заставляет вас чувствовать себя раздражительным?»	At that point, curiosity increases. Self sends the part the energy of curiosity. Self wants to know and understand the experiences of this part and wants it to feel Self’s desire to get to know it better. Self asks, “What do you want me to know about you?” The part quickly responds, “My name is Prickly, spelled P-R-I-C-K-L-E-E, never L-Y.” The way she emphasizes never gives Self the sense that the distinction is very important. “Got it, Pricklee, L-E-E. What about life not going as you expect causes you to feel irritable?”
She responds, “I like to know how things are going to turn out. I don’t like it when the unpredictable happens. I want to be prepared for bad things.” Self is now curious about the connection between the unexpected and bad things happening. Self says, “It makes sense to want to be prepared in case something bad happens. Have unexpected bad things happened to you?” Pricklee emphatically says, “Yes, they have.” “I’m interested to know more about that,” Self says in an inquiring tone. Pricklee totally relaxes her (my) jaw as she projects her experiences as a movie playing before my eyes.	She responds, “I like to know how things are going to turn out. I don’t like it when the unpredictable happens. I want to be prepared for bad things.” Self is now curious about the connection between the unexpected and bad things happening. Self says, “It makes sense to want to be prepared in case something bad happens. Have unexpected bad things happened to you?” Pricklee emphatically says, “Yes, they have.” “I’m interested to know more about that,” Self says in an inquiring tone. Pricklee totally relaxes her (my) jaw as she projects her experiences as a movie playing before my eyes.	Она отвечает: «Мне нравится знать, как все обернется. Я не люблю, когда случается непредсказуемое. Я хочу быть готовым к плохим вещам». Селфу теперь интересно узнать о связи между происходящими неожиданными и плохими событиями. Селф говорит: «Имеет смысл быть готовым на случай, если произойдет что-то плохое. С тобой случались неожиданные плохие вещи?» Прикли решительно говорит: «Да, они это сделали». «Мне интересно узнать об этом больше», — говорит Селф вопросительным тоном. Прикли полностью расслабляет свою (мою) челюсть, проецируя свои переживания как фильм, который идет у меня на глазах.	She responds, “I like to know how things are going to turn out. I don’t like it when the unpredictable happens. I want to be prepared for bad things.” Self is now curious about the connection between the unexpected and bad things happening. Self says, “It makes sense to want to be prepared in case something bad happens. Have unexpected bad things happened to you?” Pricklee emphatically says, “Yes, they have.” “I’m interested to know more about that,” Self says in an inquiring tone. Pricklee totally relaxes her (my) jaw as she projects her experiences as a movie playing before my eyes.
The first scene is of me at about age nine traveling on a plane with my younger sister and brother to visit our paternal grandparents in Louisiana for the summer. I see a stewardess attending to us with food and beverages. I feel the excitement and fear in my physical body that my younger self felt during the flight. I see myself coloring happily in a book about planes and travel. I’m then shown a scene of the stewardess pinning golden wings on the lapel of my blouse. I sense that my younger self felt so special.	The first scene is of me at about age nine traveling on a plane with my younger sister and brother to visit our paternal grandparents in Louisiana for the summer. I see a stewardess attending to us with food and beverages. I feel the excitement and fear in my physical body that my younger self felt during the flight. I see myself coloring happily in a book about planes and travel. I’m then shown a scene of the stewardess pinning golden wings on the lapel of my blouse. I sense that my younger self felt so special.	В первой сцене я лет девяти лет летаю на самолете с младшей сестрой и братом, чтобы навестить летом наших бабушку и дедушку по отцовской линии в Луизиане. Я вижу, как стюардесса обслуживает нас с едой и напитками. Я чувствую волнение и страх в своем физическом теле, которые чувствовала моя молодая личность во время полета. Я вижу себя счастливо раскрашивающим книгу о самолетах и ​​путешествиях. Затем мне показывают сцену, где стюардесса прикрепляет золотые крылья к лацкану моей блузки. Я чувствую, что я в молодости чувствовал себя таким особенным.	The first scene is of me at about age nine traveling on a plane with my younger sister and brother to visit our paternal grandparents in Louisiana for the summer. I see a stewardess attending to us with food and beverages. I feel the excitement and fear in my physical body that my younger self felt during the flight. I see myself coloring happily in a book about planes and travel. I’m then shown a scene of the stewardess pinning golden wings on the lapel of my blouse. I sense that my younger self felt so special.
The next scene is a montage of various activities and experiences while visiting that summer. My two youngest aunts were home from college. They were both in their early 20s at the time. I saw flashes of them taking me to the public swimming pool, to Grambling State University where they both attended college, to the local grocery store to get candy, chips, and soda. Next, I saw myself eating figs off the tree in the yard until my stomach hurt. My grandmother teaching me to sew on her black-and-gold Singer sewing machine with the large circle thing that made the needle go up and down. We were making dresses for my Barbie dolls. Pricklee even played a scene of me getting into mischief with my cousins throwing rocks at the glass-paned roof of an abandoned plant nursery. In these scenes, I felt Pricklee’s light expansiveness of joy and playfulness.	The next scene is a montage of various activities and experiences while visiting that summer. My two youngest aunts were home from college. They were both in their early 20s at the time. I saw flashes of them taking me to the public swimming pool, to Grambling State University where they both attended college, to the local grocery store to get candy, chips, and soda. Next, I saw myself eating figs off the tree in the yard until my stomach hurt. My grandmother teaching me to sew on her black-and-gold Singer sewing machine with the large circle thing that made the needle go up and down. We were making dresses for my Barbie dolls. Pricklee even played a scene of me getting into mischief with my cousins throwing rocks at the glass-paned roof of an abandoned plant nursery. In these scenes, I felt Pricklee’s light expansiveness of joy and playfulness.	Следующая сцена представляет собой монтаж различных мероприятий и впечатлений во время посещения того лета. Две мои младшие тети вернулись из колледжа. Им обоим тогда было около 20 лет. Я видела, как они везли меня в общественный бассейн, в Государственный университет Грэмблинга, где они оба учились в колледже, в местный продуктовый магазин за конфетами, чипсами и газировкой. Затем я увидел, как ем инжир с дерева во дворе, пока у меня не заболел живот. Моя бабушка учила меня шить на своей черно-золотой швейной машине Singer с большим круглым предметом, который заставлял иглу подниматься и опускаться. Мы шили платья для моих кукол Барби. Прикли даже разыграл сцену, в которой я шалил с моими кузенами, швыряющими камни в стеклянную крышу заброшенного питомника растений. В этих сценах я почувствовал легкую широту радости и игривости Прикли.	The next scene is a montage of various activities and experiences while visiting that summer. My two youngest aunts were home from college. They were both in their early 20s at the time. I saw flashes of them taking me to the public swimming pool, to Grambling State University where they both attended college, to the local grocery store to get candy, chips, and soda. Next, I saw myself eating figs off the tree in the yard until my stomach hurt. My grandmother teaching me to sew on her black-and-gold Singer sewing machine with the large circle thing that made the needle go up and down. We were making dresses for my Barbie dolls. Pricklee even played a scene of me getting into mischief with my cousins throwing rocks at the glass-paned roof of an abandoned plant nursery. In these scenes, I felt Pricklee’s light expansiveness of joy and playfulness.
The final scenes begin with my nine-year-old self going to the mailbox at the road to collect the mail, which was one of her daily chores. She recognized the bold, strong box lettering on one of the envelopes as her father’s printing. The next thing she noticed literally took her breath away. The return address was not her home address in Marina del Rey, California, but an unknown address in Inglewood, California. She was confused and didn’t understand why her father would have a new, different address. I could feel the strain of her trying to make sense of what she read. Wondering if this was the address of the apartment building he and Mom owned. But why would he put that address on the envelope? Although she didn’t understand, she felt that something was very wrong. She ran into the house with tears on her face, demanding that her grandmother tell her why her father had a new address. Her grandmother said she didn’t know, but my younger self knew she was lying. Pricklee next showed a scene of me asking my grandmother what the letter said. My grandmother refused, saying, “It’s not mine to tell.” I felt nine-year-old Tamala’s outrage at the truth being withheld and her terror of the unknown.	The final scenes begin with my nine-year-old self going to the mailbox at the road to collect the mail, which was one of her daily chores. She recognized the bold, strong box lettering on one of the envelopes as her father’s printing. The next thing she noticed literally took her breath away. The return address was not her home address in Marina del Rey, California, but an unknown address in Inglewood, California. She was confused and didn’t understand why her father would have a new, different address. I could feel the strain of her trying to make sense of what she read. Wondering if this was the address of the apartment building he and Mom owned. But why would he put that address on the envelope? Although she didn’t understand, she felt that something was very wrong. She ran into the house with tears on her face, demanding that her grandmother tell her why her father had a new address. Her grandmother said she didn’t know, but my younger self knew she was lying. Pricklee next showed a scene of me asking my grandmother what the letter said. My grandmother refused, saying, “It’s not mine to tell.” I felt nine-year-old Tamala’s outrage at the truth being withheld and her terror of the unknown.	Финальные сцены начинаются с того, что я, девятилетняя девочка, иду к почтовому ящику на дороге, чтобы забрать почту, что было одной из ее ежедневных обязанностей. Она узнала в жирных, ярких буквах на одном из конвертов печать своего отца. Следующее, что она заметила, у нее буквально перехватило дыхание. Обратным адресом был не ее домашний адрес в Марина-дель-Рей, Калифорния, а неизвестный адрес в Инглвуде, Калифорния. Она была в замешательстве и не понимала, почему у ее отца новый, другой адрес. Я чувствовал напряжение, с которым она пыталась понять смысл прочитанного. Интересно, был ли это адрес многоквартирного дома, которым владели они с мамой? Но зачем ему писать этот адрес на конверте? Хоть она и не понимала, но чувствовала, что что-то не так. Она вбежала в дом со слезами на лице, требуя от бабушки рассказать ей, почему у ее отца новый адрес. Ее бабушка сказала, что не знает, но я в молодости знал, что она лжет. Затем Прикли показал сцену, где я спрашиваю бабушку, о чем говорится в письме. Бабушка отказалась, сказав: «Не мне рассказывать». Я почувствовал возмущение девятилетней Тамалы по поводу сокрытия правды и ее ужас перед неизвестным.	The final scenes begin with my nine-year-old self going to the mailbox at the road to collect the mail, which was one of her daily chores. She recognized the bold, strong box lettering on one of the envelopes as her father’s printing. The next thing she noticed literally took her breath away. The return address was not her home address in Marina del Rey, California, but an unknown address in Inglewood, California. She was confused and didn’t understand why her father would have a new, different address. I could feel the strain of her trying to make sense of what she read. Wondering if this was the address of the apartment building he and Mom owned. But why would he put that address on the envelope? Although she didn’t understand, she felt that something was very wrong. She ran into the house with tears on her face, demanding that her grandmother tell her why her father had a new address. Her grandmother said she didn’t know, but my younger self knew she was lying. Pricklee next showed a scene of me asking my grandmother what the letter said. My grandmother refused, saying, “It’s not mine to tell.” I felt nine-year-old Tamala’s outrage at the truth being withheld and her terror of the unknown.
Gone were the carefree days of cheerfully swimming, sewing, and eating handpicked figs. She was consumed with wanting to know the contents of her father’s letter and the significance of the return address. No one would tell her what was going on back home. Everyone claimed to have no idea. She begged and cried to go home. She believed she could fix whatever was wrong if she could return. She was only told she would talk to her parents soon. When she finally spoke with her parents by phone, they just told her to enjoy her summer and they would talk about it when she got home. Which was all she wanted to do, go home. The phone call left her anxious and fearful.	Gone were the carefree days of cheerfully swimming, sewing, and eating handpicked figs. She was consumed with wanting to know the contents of her father’s letter and the significance of the return address. No one would tell her what was going on back home. Everyone claimed to have no idea. She begged and cried to go home. She believed she could fix whatever was wrong if she could return. She was only told she would talk to her parents soon. When she finally spoke with her parents by phone, they just told her to enjoy her summer and they would talk about it when she got home. Which was all she wanted to do, go home. The phone call left her anxious and fearful.	Прошли те беззаботные дни, когда мы весело купались, шили и ели собранный вручную инжир. Ее охватило желание узнать содержание письма отца и значение обратного адреса. Никто не рассказывал ей, что происходит дома. Все утверждали, что понятия не имеют. Она умоляла и плакала, чтобы она пошла домой. Она верила, что сможет исправить все, что было не так, если вернется. Ей только сказали, что она скоро поговорит с родителями. Когда она наконец поговорила с родителями по телефону, они просто сказали ей наслаждаться летом и поговорить об этом, когда она вернется домой. Единственное, чего ей хотелось, — пойти домой. Телефонный звонок вызвал у нее тревогу и страх.	Gone were the carefree days of cheerfully swimming, sewing, and eating handpicked figs. She was consumed with wanting to know the contents of her father’s letter and the significance of the return address. No one would tell her what was going on back home. Everyone claimed to have no idea. She begged and cried to go home. She believed she could fix whatever was wrong if she could return. She was only told she would talk to her parents soon. When she finally spoke with her parents by phone, they just told her to enjoy her summer and they would talk about it when she got home. Which was all she wanted to do, go home. The phone call left her anxious and fearful.
The next thing my nine-year-old self communicates comes in the feeling of having the wind knocked out of her. She felt blindsided and abandoned. There was no one to help her manage her overwhelming feelings. Her heart physically hurt, and she didn’t understand the agonizing pain. Her tears began to flow from my eyes. I felt the intensity of her suffering and desperation. She didn’t want to face what she knew. She wanted someone to tell her that her fears were not true, but their secrecy only confirmed them. She had sensed high tension between her parents before she left for Louisiana. She knew her mother was unhappy. In her mind, her parents’ fighting, not speaking to each other, her mother’s unhappiness, and her father’s new address meant her parents were getting a divorce and her father had moved out.
